user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtAssert_Message:
```c
void UtAssert_Message(uint8 MessageType, const char *File, uint32 Line, const char *Spec, ...)
{
    va_list     va;
    char        FinalMessage[256];
    const char *BaseName;
    size_t      MsgLen;

    if (File != NULL)
    {
        BaseName = strrchr(File, '/');
        if (BaseName == NULL)
        {
            BaseName = File;
        }
        else
        {
            ++BaseName;
        }
        snprintf(FinalMessage, sizeof(FinalMessage), "%s:%u:", BaseName, (unsigned int)Line);
        MsgLen = strlen(FinalMessage);
    }
    else
    {
        MsgLen = 0;
    }

    va_start(va, Spec);
    vsnprintf(&FinalMessage[MsgLen], sizeof(FinalMessage) - MsgLen, Spec, va);
    va_end(va);

    UT_BSP_DoText(MessageType, FinalMessage);
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
UT_BSP_DoText(MessageType, FinalMessage);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation if UT_BSP_DoText is declared to take a const-qualified pointer (e.g. void UT_BSP_DoText(uint8 MessageType, const char *Text)); the call UT_BSP_DoText(MessageType, FinalMessage) then passes a modifiable buffer to a const parameter which is allowed. A violation occurs if the UT_BSP_DoText prototype uses a non-const char * (e.g. void UT_BSP_DoText(uint8, char *)) but the function does not need to modify the string — in that case the parameter should be declared as const char * per MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13.
